mediasAPI.title: Academic Grade Management and Projection REST API

apresentacao.title: Overview
apresentacao.p1: An intelligent academic management platform that transforms how students and professors handle assessments. The solution offers centralized grade storage, automatic average calculation, and primarily strategic projections that allow users to simulate scenarios and plan their performance in advance.
apresentacao.p2: The differentiator lies in flexibility: each course can have its own custom calculation method through customizable mathematical expressions. The system processes these expressions dynamically, identifies variables and constants through regex, and applies the Shunting Yard algorithm with reverse Polish notation (RPN) to ensure correct operator precedence — all without compromising performance or usability.
apresentacao.p3: Developed following SOLID principles and layered architecture, the API combines robust validations (Bean Validation), JWT authentication, automated tests with mocks, and OpenAPI 3 documentation. The solution was containerized with Docker and uses Spring Data JPA for optimized queries, demonstrating a complete and professional backend implementation.

motivacao.title: Motivation and Solution
motivacao.p1: During the academic journey at university, managing grades or even just storing them is a process that can be automated efficiently. However, as each professor and course define their own evaluation methods and performance criteria according to their preferences and approaches, there is great variability and flexibility in this process.
motivacao.p2: For the application to support these custom definitions, a solution based on regular expression processing was implemented, allowing dynamic identification and manipulation of variables, constants, and operators. This way, the calculation of final averages is automated flexibly and adaptable to different evaluation rules.
motivacao.p3: Another challenge was implementing this dynamic calculation. The adopted solution uses reverse Polish notation (RPN), which eliminates the need for parentheses by defining the correct order of precedence directly in its structure. Additionally, an adaptation of the Shunting Yard algorithm was employed, using stacks and lists as data structures to ensure correct expression evaluation.

financeAPI.title: GraphQL API for Banking Integration, Analysis and Transaction Classification

apresentacao.title: Overview
apresentacao.p1: A complete GraphQL API for intelligent financial management that connects the Open Finance ecosystem to the end user. The platform automatically captures banking transactions via webhooks, organizes movements into custom categories, and offers detailed analyses with automatic balance calculation — all through flexible and precise GraphQL queries.
apresentacao.p2: The system was designed to solve a real problem: the difficulty of consolidating and categorizing financial movements from multiple accounts. Through integration with the Pluggy aggregator in a sandbox environment, the API simulates the behavior of an Open Finance participating institution, processing webhooks in real-time and persisting data with complex relationships in PostgreSQL.
apresentacao.p3: The architecture implements messaging with Kafka for asynchronous processing, Spring Security with X-API-KEY authentication, and uses GraphQL to provide clients (dashboards, mobile apps, integrations) the flexibility to request exactly the necessary data. The project demonstrates deep knowledge in external API integration, real-time event processing, and modern GraphQL-oriented API design.

motivacao.title: Motivation and Solution
motivacao.p1: The initial intention was to build an integrated and functional system capable of automatically processing financial movements. However, obtaining, classifying, and analyzing banking transactions in real-time is a process that demands a high level of integration with financial institutions. Direct access to real banking data requires authorization as an institution in Open Finance. To pursue this purpose, a solution was implemented using a financial data aggregator that offers a sandbox environment, simulating the behavior of an Open Finance participating institution. Thus, it was possible to simulate webhooks, testing real scenarios without depending on sensitive data.
motivacao.p2: Another relevant point was the choice of GraphQL, which enables flexible and precise queries, returning only the truly necessary data for each client or integration. This facilitates the construction of dynamic dashboards and front-end applications, as well as personal analysis.
motivacao.p3: Additionally, the API allows intelligent transaction categorization, enabling the end user or application to select only relevant entries and automatically calculate the balance for analysis, filtering, or integration with custom financial reports.
